title: 105_s2503
content:
The "Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Equity Act of 1998" includes provisions for the establishment of a Commission, development of a Code of Land Grant Claims Procedure, examination of land claims, and creation of a Community Land Grant Study Center. It also grants miscellaneous powers to the Commission, requires a report, and authorizes appropriations. The "Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Equity Act of 1998" establishes the Commission for Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims. It defines terms like Commission, Treaty of Guadalupe-Hidalgo, and eligible descendant. Eligible descendants must have been Mexican citizens before the treaty, members of a community land grant, and became US citizens within ten years after the treaty. The term "community land grant" refers to land held in common by three or more families under a grant from the King of Spain or the Republic of Mexico before specific dates. "Reconstituted" means restoration to full municipality status for a valid community land grant. Congress recognizes New Mexico's unique history with Spanish and Mexican land grants, which have not been fully implemented according to the Treaty of Guadalupe-Hidalgo. Serious questions remain about the ownership of certain public lands in the state. Certain public lands in the State of New Mexico still exist, and Congress has used land claim commissions in the past to examine disputed land possession questions successfully. Establishment and membership of commission. The Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Commission is established with five members appointed by the President. At least two members must be eligible descendants with knowledge of New Mexico land grants history and law. Members serve for the life of the Commission and receive compensation at level V of the Executive Schedule. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Guadalupe-Hidalgo Treaty Land Claims Commission aims to obtain relevant documents on community land grants in New Mexico through bilateral agreements with Mexico and Spain. Additionally, a code of land grant claims procedures is being developed. The Commission will develop procedures for land grant evaluations, including criteria for legal community land grants, admissible evidence, presumptions from previous adjudications, and procedural rules for burden of proof. The Commission proposes safeguards to protect private property owners, water rights, and Native American lands in the process of land grant evaluations. The Commission outlines provisions for access to sacred sites by Tribes and Pueblos, identification of sites during the development of land grant procedures, rights and responsibilities of community land grantees, and any other necessary items. The Commission must submit the Code of Land Claims Procedure to the Senate and House Committees for review within 90 days. Evaluations of specific community land claims cannot begin before this period. SEC. 6. EXAMINATION OF LAND CLAIMS IN NEW MEXICO. SEC. 6. EXAMINATION OF LAND CLAIMS IN NEW MEXICO.

(a) Submission of New Mexico Land Claims Petitions.--Three or more eligible descendants of the same community land grant can file a petition with the Commission seeking a determination of the land claim's validity.

(b) Deadline for Submission.--Petitions must be received by the Commission within five years after the completion of the 90-day review period by the House Committees.

(c) Elements of Petition.--The petition must be made under oath and include the names and addresses of the eligible descendants who are petitioners. The petition for examination of land claims in New Mexico must include the names and addresses of eligible descendants, details about the community land grant, the petitioners' residency or intention to settle on the land, and all known facts and relevant documents. The Commission in New Mexico holds hearings on land petitions, allowing interested parties to appear. They have the power to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to the petitions. Failure to comply with a subpoena may result in consequences. The Commission in New Mexico can issue subpoenas to compel individuals to testify or provide evidence related to land petitions. Failure to comply may result in civil contempt charges. Subpoenas are served following the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure for United States district courts. The Commission in New Mexico can issue subpoenas in the judicial district where the person resides. The decision of the Commission determines the validity of a community land grant and includes a recommendation on reconstitution and land restoration. The decision does not affect non-Federal property ownership or rights. The Commission in New Mexico can issue subpoenas in the judicial district where the person resides. The recommendation under subsection (f) regarding reconstitution and land restoration of a community land grant does not involve non-Federal lands. If a valid petition covers lands in non-Federal ownership, the Commission will recommend substituting comparable Federal lands in New Mexico. The Commission in New Mexico will establish a Community Land Grant Study Center at the Onate Center in Alcalde to conduct research and investigations for its duties under this Act. Additionally, the Commission will have miscellaneous powers as outlined in Section 8. The Commission may hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and accept gifts to aid its work. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can use the United States mails. The Commission may use the United States mails and receive administrative support services. It is considered an agency of the United States for immunity purposes. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress after making decisions, including recommendations on reconstituting community land grants. The Commission will terminate 180 days after submitting its final report. $1,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 1999 to 2007 for Commission activities and the Community Land Grant Study Center.
